comments:
Build: I-20040604-1600

1. Fresh workspace.
2. Using the plug-in import wizard, import org.eclipse.core.runtime with 
source.
3. Launch a runtime workbench.  It should come up fine.  Close it.  In the 
osgi.bundles key of config.ini for this launch, PDE puts the location of the 
core.runtime plug-in project as the location of the core.runtime plug-in.
4. Close the org.eclipse.core.runtime project in your host workspace.
5. Try to launch again.  This time, of course, PDE put the location of the 
core.runtime plug-in in the Eclipse install, since the core.runtime project is 
closed.  
Surprisingly, the runtime workbench will not start due to an error that is 
attached below.

It seems to the runtime is caching the location of core.runtime from the first 
launch.

Not sure if this is a regression or that this behavior has been there all 
along and has now been exposed because the default behavior of the runtime 
workbench launcher is to NOT wipe out the config area with every launch.  
Since more and more users are using the config area for their own purposes, 
e.g. config-scope preferences, etc, users were puzzled why their config area 
was being wiped out.  So the default is to not wipe it out, much like the 
default for clearing of the workspace.  

Regardless of whether the config area is being wiped out or not, this error 
must not occur since PDE is always passing the correct location of the 
core.runtime plug-in.



!SESSION Jun 05, 2004 22:08:52.324 --------------------------------------------

This very much a friend of the various reports where people manually tweak 
their install and expect the runtime to pick that up.  We can but it is not the 
normal mode of operation as it is too costly and all too rare in production 
situations.

In this case you are going to want to start the target with -clean.  This will 
cause, amoung other things, any generated manifest.mfs to be regenerated based 
on the current code.  

Please try that and report.  

In the mean time, we will investigate the possibility that the old runtime is 
not being uninstalled before reinstalling the new runtime.  EclipseStarter 
should be doing this.

The launch configuration became usable again after adding -clean to the 
program args.

There is a problem in the code that checks for inconsistencies in the startup 
bundles.  We first try to install the list of bundles from the osgi.bundles 
list.  In this scenario we try to install the runtime bundle from a different 
location (from the eclipse install), but the runtime bundle is already 
installed from the workspace location so the install fails.  Then we detect 
that the old location is no longer valid and we uninstall the original 
location of the runtime bundle.  So now we are left in a state where no 
runtime bundle is installed!  This is a very bad state and it causes the crash.

I will look to fix this for RC2.  Wassim, please do NOT add any logic to PDE 
to start passing -clean on the commandline for each runtime start.

Created an attachment (id=11750)
Patch to review for RC2

Jeff, please review patch for approval for RC2.  Thanks.

Patch looks good.  suggest breaking up loadBasicBundles() into 

uninstall
install
refresh
start

to make it all more readable.

Release when ready.

Created an attachment (id=11763)
Final patch RC2 fix

Did the suggested change to split up loadBasicBundles().  Will integrate this
code for the 8:00 RC2 build.
Fix will make it into the 8:00 RC2 build.
